docs.title: PortGuard 🛡️
docs.text:
A lightweight, configurable HTTP service for monitoring port availability and health checking. Perfect for load balancers, Kubernetes health probes, and service monitoring.

📚 Quick Start | 📖 Examples | ❓ FAQ

docs.title: Features
docs.text: ✨ Simple & Lightweight - Single binary, minimal dependencies ⚙️ Configurable - YAML-based configuration 🔍 Detailed Health Checks - JSON responses with per-port status 🔒 Secure - Optional HTTP Basic Authentication 🚀 Production Ready - Systemd, Docker, Kubernetes support

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Download latest release
wget https://github.com/mrwogu/portguard/releases/latest/download/portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz
tar -xzf portguard-*.tar.gz

# Create config
mkdir -p /etc/portguard
cp config.yaml.example /etc/portguard/config.yaml
nano /etc/portguard/config.yaml

# Run
./portguard

📖 See Quick Start Guide for detailed installation instructions including Docker, systemd, and other platforms.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
server:
  port: "8888"
  timeout: 2s  # Default timeout for all checks

  # Optional: HTTP Basic Authentication
  auth:
    enabled: false  # Set to true to enable
    username: "admin"
    password: "secure-password"

checks:
  - host: "mail.example.com"
    port: 25
    name: "SMTP"
    description: "Mail Transfer Protocol"
    # Uses default timeout (2s)

  - host: "remote-api.example.com"
    port: 443
    name: "Remote API"
    description: "Remote API endpoint"
    timeout: 10s  # Custom timeout for this check

📖 See Examples for more configuration examples (web apps, databases, Kubernetes, microservices).

docs.title: API Endpoints
docs.text:
• /health - Detailed JSON status (200 OK = healthy, 503 = unhealthy)
  • /live - Simple liveness probe (always returns 200 OK)
  • / - HTML info page

📖 See FAQ for integration examples with HAProxy, Nginx, and Kubernetes.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: This project and everyone participating in it is governed by our Code of Conduct. By participating, you are expected to uphold this code.

docs.title: Reporting Bugs
docs.text:
Before creating bug reports, please check the existing issues as you might find out that you don't need to create one. When you are creating a bug report, please include as many details as possible:

  • Use a clear and descriptive title
  • Describe the exact steps which reproduce the problem
  • Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps
  • Describe the behavior you observed after following the steps
  • Explain which behavior you expected to see instead and why
  • Include logs and configuration files (sanitize sensitive data)

docs.title: Suggesting Enhancements
docs.text:
Enhancement suggestions are tracked as GitHub issues. When creating an enhancement suggestion, please include:

  • Use a clear and descriptive title
  • Provide a step-by-step description of the suggested enhancement
  • Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps
  • Describe the current behavior and explain which behavior you expected to see instead
  • Explain why this enhancement would be useful

docs.title: Pull Requests
docs.text:
• Fill in the required template
  • Do not include issue numbers in the PR title
  • Follow the Go coding style
  • Include thoughtfully-worded, well-structured tests
  • Document new code
  • End all files with a newline

docs.title: Development Process
docs.text:

docs.title: PortGuard Example Configurations
docs.text: This directory contains example configurations for various use cases.

docs.title: Secured Configuration with HTTP Basic Auth
docs.text:
Protect your PortGuard endpoints with HTTP Basic Authentication:

server:
  port: "8888"
  timeout: 2s
  auth:
    enabled: true
    username: "admin"
    password: "your-secure-password-here"

checks:
  - host: "localhost"
    port: 443
    name: "HTTPS"
    description: "Web Server HTTPS"

Access the endpoints with authentication:

# Using curl with basic auth
curl -u admin:your-secure-password-here http://localhost:8888/health

# Using wget with basic auth
wget --user=admin --password=your-secure-password-here http://localhost:8888/health

Security Note: Store credentials securely. Consider using environment variables or secret management tools in production environments.

docs.title: Per-Check Timeout Configuration
docs.text:
Configure different timeouts for each service based on its characteristics:

server:
  port: "8888"
  timeout: 2s  # Default timeout

checks:
  # Fast local services - quick timeout
  - host: "localhost"
    port: 6379
    name: "Redis"
    description: "Local cache"
    timeout: 500ms  # Fast check for local service

  - host: "localhost"
    port: 11211
    name: "Memcached"
    description: "Memory cache"
    timeout: 500ms

  # Local services - use default timeout (2s)
  - host: "localhost"
    port: 5432
    name: "PostgreSQL"
    description: "Database server"
    # No timeout specified, uses server default (2s)

  # Remote/slow services - longer timeout
  - host: "remote-api.example.com"
    port: 443
    name: "External API"
    description: "Third-party API endpoint"
    timeout: 10s  # Longer timeout for remote service

  - host: "backup.example.com"
    port: 873
    name: "Rsync Backup"
    description: "Remote backup server"
    timeout: 15s  # Very long timeout for potentially slow service

  # Mixed local network services
  - host: "10.0.1.50"
    port: 8080
    name: "Microservice A"
    description: "Internal service"
    timeout: 3s

  - host: "10.0.1.51"
    port: 8080
    name: "Microservice B"
    description: "Internal service"
    # Uses default timeout

This configuration demonstrates: - Fast checks (500ms) for local caching services - Default timeout (2s) for standard services (when not specified) - Long timeouts (10-15s) for remote or potentially slow services - Custom timeouts (3s) for specific needs

docs.title: What is PortGuard?
docs.text: PortGuard is a lightweight HTTP service that monitors TCP port availability. It provides health check endpoints that return JSON status information, making it perfect for load balancers, monitoring systems, and Kubernetes health probes.

docs.title: Why should I use PortGuard instead of [other tool]?
docs.text: PortGuard is: - Simple: Single binary, no dependencies - Fast: Written in Go for performance - Flexible: YAML configuration for any ports - Standard: Returns HTTP 200/503 status codes - Production-ready: Includes systemd service, Docker support

docs.title: Is PortGuard production-ready?
docs.text: Yes! PortGuard is designed for production use with: - Proper error handling - Configurable timeouts - Systemd service support - Docker support - Comprehensive logging

docs.title: Where should I put the config file?
docs.text:
Default location: /etc/portguard/config.yaml

You can also specify a custom location: 

portguard --config /path/to/config.yaml

docs.title: How do I monitor multiple servers?
docs.text:
Add multiple checks in your config:

checks:
  - host: "server1.example.com"
    port: 80
    name: "Server 1"
  - host: "server2.example.com"
    port: 80
    name: "Server 2"

docs.title: Can I monitor localhost ports?
docs.text:
Yes! Just use localhost or 127.0.0.1:

checks:
  - host: "localhost"
    port: 8080
    name: "Local App"

docs.title: What timeout should I use?
docs.text:
• Local services: 1-2s
  • Same datacenter: 2-3s
  • Remote services: 5-10s
  • Slow connections: 10-30s
server:
  timeout: 5s  # Adjust based on your needs

docs.title: Can I monitor UDP ports?
docs.text: Not yet. PortGuard currently only supports TCP ports. UDP support is on the roadmap.

docs.title: How do I secure PortGuard endpoints?
docs.text:
PortGuard supports HTTP Basic Authentication. Enable it in your config:

server:
  port: "8888"
  timeout: 2s
  auth:
    enabled: true
    username: "admin"
    password: "your-secure-password"

When authentication is enabled, all endpoints (/health, /live, /) require valid credentials.

docs.title: Is authentication required?
docs.text:
No, authentication is disabled by default. Enable it only when needed:

auth:
  enabled: false  # Default - no authentication required

docs.title: How secure is HTTP Basic Auth?
docs.text:
HTTP Basic Auth sends credentials as base64-encoded strings. For production:

  1. Always use HTTPS - Deploy behind a reverse proxy (nginx, Traefik, Caddy) with TLS
  2. Use strong passwords - Generate random, long passwords
  3. Rotate credentials - Change passwords periodically
  4. Use secret management - Store credentials in environment variables or secret managers

Example with environment variables:

# Store password securely
export PORTGUARD_PASSWORD="$(openssl rand -base64 32)"

# Use in config (requires templating or script to inject)

docs.title: Can I use different authentication for different endpoints?
docs.text: No, currently all endpoints share the same authentication settings. This is intentional to keep the configuration simple.

docs.title: Should I enable authentication for Kubernetes health probes?
docs.text:
It depends on your security requirements:

  • Without auth: Simpler, works out-of-the-box with Kubernetes
  • With auth: More secure, requires creating a Secret and configuring probes

Example Kubernetes probe with authentication:

livenessProbe:
  httpGet:
    path: /live
    port: 8888
    httpHeaders:
    - name: Authorization
      value: Basic YWRtaW46cGFzc3dvcmQ=  # base64 encoded "admin:password"

Better approach - use a Secret:

# Create secret
kubectl create secret generic portguard-auth \
  --from-literal=username=admin \
  --from-literal=password=secure-password

docs.title: How do I install PortGuard?
docs.text:
See the Quick Start Guide for detailed instructions. Quick summary:

# Download binary
wget https://github.com/mrwogu/portguard/releases/latest/download/portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz
tar -xzf portguard-*.tar.gz
sudo mv portguard-* /usr/local/bin/portguard

# Create config
sudo mkdir -p /etc/portguard
sudo nano /etc/portguard/config.yaml

# Run
portguard

docs.title: How do I run PortGuard in Docker?
docs.text:
docker run -d \
  -p 8888:8888 \
  -v /path/to/config.yaml:/etc/portguard/config.yaml:ro \
  ghcr.io/mrwogu/portguard:latest

docs.title: How do I install as a systemd service?
docs.text:
sudo make install

Or manually: 

sudo cp portguard /opt/portguard/
sudo cp portguard.service /etc/systemd/system/
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl start portguard
sudo systemctl enable portguard

docs.title: Can I run multiple instances?
docs.text:
Yes! Just use different config files and ports:

portguard --config /etc/portguard/config1.yaml &
portguard --config /etc/portguard/config2.yaml &

docs.title: What endpoints are available?
docs.text:
• /health - Detailed health status (JSON)
  • /live - Simple liveness check (text)
  • / - Information page (HTML)

docs.title: How do I integrate with my load balancer?
docs.text:
HAProxy: 

option httpchk GET /health
http-check expect status 200

Nginx: 

health_check uri=/health;

See the README for more examples.

docs.title: How do I use with Kubernetes?
docs.text:
livenessProbe:
  httpGet:
    path: /live
    port: 8888
readinessProbe:
  httpGet:
    path: /health
    port: 8888

docs.title: What do the status codes mean?
docs.text:
• 200 OK: All monitored ports are healthy
  • 503 Service Unavailable: One or more ports are unhealthy
  • 404 Not Found: Invalid endpoint

docs.title: How do I check only specific services?
docs.text: Configure only the ports you want to monitor in config.yaml. PortGuard only checks what you configure.

docs.title: PortGuard says a port is unhealthy, but it's working
docs.text:
Possible causes:

  1. Firewall: Check firewall rules 

    sudo iptables -L

  2. Network: Test connectivity 

    telnet hostname port

  3. Timeout: Increase timeout in config 

    server:
  timeout: 10s

  4. DNS: Verify hostname resolution 

    nslookup hostname

docs.title: Port 8888 is already in use
docs.text:
Change the port in config:

server:
  port: "9999"

docs.title: Permission denied errors
docs.text: Either: - Run with sudo: sudo portguard - Use a port > 1024 in config - Set capabilities: sudo setcap 'cap_net_bind_service=+ep' /path/to/portguard

docs.title: Config file not found
docs.text:
Specify the config file explicitly:

portguard --config /path/to/config.yaml

docs.title: How do I enable debug logging?
docs.text:
Currently, PortGuard logs to stdout. Run it in foreground to see logs:

portguard --config config.yaml

With systemd: 

sudo journalctl -u portguard -f

docs.title: Checks are slow
docs.text:
Possible solutions:

  1. Reduce timeout (if appropriate)
  2. Check network latency
  3. Verify target services are responsive
  4. Use localhost for local services

docs.title: How many ports can I monitor?
docs.text: PortGuard can monitor hundreds of ports efficiently. Each check is independent and runs concurrently.

docs.title: What's the resource usage?
docs.text: Very minimal: - Memory: ~10-20 MB - CPU: <1% when idle - Network: Minimal (only health checks)

docs.title: Can I monitor thousands of ports?
docs.text: Yes, but consider: - Network bandwidth - Check frequency (via external monitoring) - Target service load

docs.title: Is PortGuard secure?
docs.text: PortGuard follows security best practices: - No authentication by default (use firewall/proxy) - Minimal attack surface - No data storage - Runs with minimal privileges

docs.title: Should I expose PortGuard to the internet?
docs.text: No! Use it behind: - Firewall rules - VPN - Reverse proxy with authentication - Load balancer

docs.title: How do I report security issues?
docs.text: See the Security Policy for our security policy.

docs.title: How do I contribute?
docs.text: See the Contributing guide for guidelines.

docs.title: How do I build from source?
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/mrwogu/portguard.git
cd portguard
go build -o portguard main.go

Or use Make: 

make build

docs.text: make test

docs.title: PortGuard Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with PortGuard in 5 minutes!

docs.title: Step 1: Download
docs.text:
Go to Releases and download the appropriate binary for your system:

  • Linux (64-bit): portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz
  • macOS (Intel): portguard-darwin-amd64.tar.gz
  • macOS (Apple Silicon): portguard-darwin-arm64.tar.gz
  • Windows: portguard-windows-amd64.zip

docs.title: Step 2: Extract and Install
docs.text:
Linux/macOS: 

tar -xzf portguard-*.tar.gz
chmod +x portguard-*
sudo mv portguard-* /usr/local/bin/portguard

Windows: Extract the ZIP file and add the directory to your PATH.

docs.title: Step 3: Create Configuration
docs.text:
# Create config directory
sudo mkdir -p /etc/portguard

# Download example config
curl -o /tmp/config.yaml.example https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mrwogu/portguard/main/config.yaml.example

# Copy and edit
sudo cp /tmp/config.yaml.example /etc/portguard/config.yaml
sudo nano /etc/portguard/config.yaml

Edit the configuration to monitor your ports:

server:
  port: "8888"
  timeout: 2s

checks:
  - host: "your-server.com"
    port: 80
    name: "Web Server"
    description: "HTTP"

docs.title: Step 4: Run
docs.text:
# Run directly
portguard

# Or specify config location
portguard --config /etc/portguard/config.yaml

docs.title: Step 5: Test
docs.text:
Open your browser to http://localhost:8888 or use curl:

curl http://localhost:8888/health

docs.title: Quick Test
docs.text:
# Create a config file
cat > config.yaml << 'EOF'
server:
  port: "8888"
  timeout: 2s
checks:
  - host: "google.com"
    port: 443
    name: "Google"
    description: "Test connection"
EOF

# Run with Docker
docker run -d \
  --name portguard \
  -p 8888:8888 \
  -v $(pwd)/config.yaml:/etc/portguard/config.yaml:ro \
  ghcr.io/mrwogu/portguard:latest

# Check logs
docker logs portguard

# Test
curl http://localhost:8888/health

docs.title: Using Docker Compose
docs.text:
# Create docker-compose.yml
cat > docker-compose.yml << 'EOF'
version: '3.8'
services:
  portguard:
    image: ghcr.io/mrwogu/portguard:latest
    ports:
      - "8888:8888"
    volumes:
      - ./config.yaml:/etc/portguard/config.yaml:ro
    restart: unless-stopped
EOF

# Start
docker-compose up -d

# Check status
docker-compose ps

# View logs
docker-compose logs -f

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Go 1.23 or later
  • Git

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/mrwogu/portguard.git
cd portguard

# Build
go build -o portguard main.go

# Or use Make
make build

# Create config
cp config.yaml.example config.yaml
nano config.yaml

# Run
./portguard --config config.yaml

docs.title: Using Make (Recommended)
docs.text:
The Makefile includes an install target that builds the binary, installs it to /opt/portguard, installs a default config to /etc/portguard/config.yaml if one does not already exist, and copies the systemd service file.

# Build and install (requires root for system locations)
sudo make install

# Edit configuration (only if you need changes beyond the example)
sudo nano /etc/portguard/config.yaml

# Start service
sudo systemctl start portguard

# Check status
sudo systemctl status portguard

# Enable auto-start on boot
sudo systemctl enable portguard

# View logs
sudo journalctl -u portguard -f

# Uninstall (optional)
sudo make uninstall

docs.title: Manual Installation (Alternative)
docs.text:
# Copy binary
sudo mkdir -p /opt/portguard
sudo cp portguard /opt/portguard/
sudo chmod +x /opt/portguard/portguard

# Copy config
sudo mkdir -p /etc/portguard
sudo cp config.yaml.example /etc/portguard/config.yaml

# Copy service file
sudo cp portguard.service /etc/systemd/system/

# Reload and start
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl start portguard
sudo systemctl enable portguard

docs.title: 1. Check if Service is Running
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:8888/live
# Should return: OK

docs.title: 2. Check Health Status
docs.text:
curl http://localhost:8888/health | jq

Example healthy response: 

{
  "status": "healthy",
  "message": "All ports are listening and accessible",
  "checks": [
    {
      "name": "Web Server",
      "host": "example.com",
      "port": 80,
      "description": "HTTP",
      "status": "healthy"
    }
  ],
  "timestamp": "2025-10-26T10:30:00Z",
  "version": "1.0.0"
}

docs.title: 3. Run Built-in Tests
docs.text:
PortGuard includes standard Go tests. Run them with:

make test       # Runs tests with race detector and coverage
make test-coverage  # (Optional) Generates HTML coverage report

docs.title: Port Already in Use
docs.text:
If port 8888 is already in use, change it in config.yaml:

server:
  port: "9999"  # Use a different port
  timeout: 2s

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
If you get permission errors:

# Give executable permissions
chmod +x portguard

# Or run with sudo if binding to ports < 1024
sudo ./portguard

docs.title: Connection Refused
docs.text:
If checks are failing:

  1. Verify the host is reachable: ping your-host
  2. Check if the port is open: telnet your-host port
  3. Verify firewall rules
  4. Increase timeout in config if network is slow

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text: This document describes how to create a new release of PortGuard.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Releases are fully automated through GitHub Actions. When you push a version tag, the CI/CD pipeline:

  1. Runs all tests and linters
  2. Builds binaries for all platforms
  3. Packages them with checksums
  4. Creates a GitHub Release with all artifacts
  5. Builds and publishes Docker images

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before creating a release:

  • [ ] All tests pass locally: make test
  • [ ] Code is linted: make lint
  • [ ] Documentation is up to date
  • [ ] CHANGELOG.md is updated with release notes
  • [ ] Version follows Semantic Versioning

docs.title: 1. Update CHANGELOG.md
docs.text:
Add a new version section at the top:

## [1.2.0] - 2024-10-26

### Added
- New feature X
- New feature Y

### Changed
- Improved Z

### Fixed
- Bug fix for issue #123

docs.title: 2. Test Release Build Locally
docs.text:
Use the Make target:

# Test the complete release build process with explicit version
VERSION=v1.2.0 make release-test

# Or test with auto-detected version (git describe)
make release-test

This simulates the GitHub Actions workflow and creates artifacts in dist/.

docs.title: 3. Commit Changes
docs.text:
git add CHANGELOG.md
git commit -m "chore: prepare release v1.2.0"
git push origin main

docs.title: 4. Create and Push Tag
docs.text:
# Create annotated tag
git tag -a v1.2.0 -m "Release v1.2.0"

# Push tag to trigger release workflow
git push origin v1.2.0

docs.title: 5. Monitor Release
docs.text:
1. Go to GitHub Actions
  2. Watch the "Release" workflow
  3. Check for any errors

docs.title: 6. Verify Release
docs.text:
Once complete:

  1. Visit Releases page
  2. Verify all artifacts are present:
  3. portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz + .sha256
  4. portguard-linux-arm64.tar.gz + .sha256
  5. portguard-darwin-amd64.tar.gz + .sha256
  6. portguard-darwin-arm64.tar.gz + .sha256
  7. portguard-windows-amd64.zip + .sha256
  8. Check Docker images
  9. Test download and run:
# Download and test
wget https://github.com/mrwogu/portguard/releases/download/v1.2.0/portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz
tar -xzf portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz
./portguard-linux-amd64 --version

docs.title: Stable Releases
docs.text:
v1.0.0    # Major version
v1.1.0    # Minor version (new features)
v1.1.1    # Patch version (bug fixes)

docs.title: Pre-releases
docs.text:
v1.0.0-rc.1     # Release candidate
v1.0.0-beta.1   # Beta version
v1.0.0-alpha.1  # Alpha version

Pre-release versions are automatically marked as "Pre-release" on GitHub.

docs.title: Rollback
docs.text:
If you need to remove a bad release:

# Delete remote tag
git push --delete origin v1.2.0

# Delete local tag
git tag -d v1.2.0

# Delete GitHub release (manually via web UI or gh CLI)
gh release delete v1.2.0

Then fix the issue and create a new tag (e.g., v1.2.1).

docs.title: Hotfix Releases
docs.text:
For urgent bug fixes:

  1. Create a hotfix branch from the release tag: 

    git checkout -b hotfix/1.2.1 v1.2.0

  2. Make the fix and commit: 

    git commit -am "fix: critical bug"

  3. Merge back to main: 

    git checkout main
git merge --no-ff hotfix/1.2.1

  4. Tag and push: 

    git tag -a v1.2.1 -m "Release v1.2.1 - Hotfix"
git push origin main v1.2.1

docs.title: Release workflow fails on tests
docs.text:
• Fix the failing tests
  • Delete the tag: git push --delete origin v1.2.0
  • Recreate and push the tag after fixes

docs.title: Release workflow fails on build
docs.text:
• Check the build works locally: make build-all
  • Ensure Go version matches (1.23+)
  • Check for platform-specific issues

docs.title: Artifacts are missing
docs.text:
• Check GitHub Actions logs for upload errors
  • Ensure all platforms built successfully
  • Verify packaging step completed

docs.title: Docker build fails
docs.text:
• Test locally: docker build -t test -f docker/Dockerfile .
  • Check Dockerfile exists and is correct
  • Verify multi-platform build support

docs.title: Manual Release (Emergency)
docs.text:
If GitHub Actions is unavailable:

# Build locally
make build-all

# Package
cd dist
tar -czf portguard-linux-amd64.tar.gz portguard-linux-amd64
# ... repeat for other platforms

# Create checksums
shasum -a 256 *.tar.gz *.zip > checksums.txt

# Create release via GitHub CLI
gh release create v1.2.0 \
  --title "v1.2.0" \
  --notes "See CHANGELOG.md" \
  dist/*.tar.gz dist/*.zip dist/*.sha256

docs.title: Post-Release
docs.text:
After a successful release:

  1. Announce on relevant channels
  2. Update documentation sites if any
  3. Create a new section in CHANGELOG.md for next version: 
    ## [Unreleased]

### Added
### Changed
### Fixed

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• Check GitHub Actions documentation
  • Review workflow files in .github/workflows/
  • Open an issue for automation problems

docs.title: About This Project
docs.text: PortGuard is an open-source project created with passion. We do our best to maintain it, but as with any open-source software, there are no guarantees.

docs.title: Reporting a Vulnerability
docs.text:
If you discover a security vulnerability within PortGuard, please open a GitHub issue describing the problem.

We encourage you to submit a pull request with a fix - this is the fastest way to get the issue resolved. Community contributions are always welcome!

docs.title: What to Include
docs.text:
When reporting a vulnerability, please include:

  • Type of issue (e.g. buffer overflow, SQL injection, cross-site scripting, etc.)
  • Full paths of source file(s) related to the manifestation of the issue
  • The location of the affected source code (tag/branch/commit or direct URL)
  • Any special configuration required to reproduce the issue
  • Step-by-step instructions to reproduce the issue
  • Proof-of-concept or exploit code (if possible)
  • Impact of the issue, including how an attacker might exploit it

docs.title: No Guarantees
docs.text:
Please note that:

  • We cannot guarantee that we will fix every reported issue
  • Response times may vary depending on maintainer availability
  • The best way to ensure a fix is to submit a pull request yourself

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
When deploying PortGuard:

  1. Run with minimal privileges: Don't run as root unless necessary
  2. Use HTTPS: If exposing to the internet, use a reverse proxy with TLS
  3. Network isolation: Run in isolated networks when possible
  4. Keep updated: Always use the latest version
  5. Secure configuration: Protect your config files with appropriate permissions
  6. Monitor logs: Regularly review logs for suspicious activity

docs.title: Known Security Considerations
docs.text:
• PortGuard performs TCP connections to configured hosts - ensure firewall rules are appropriate
  • Configuration files may contain sensitive information (hostnames, ports) - protect with file permissions
  • The HTTP API is unauthenticated by design - use firewall rules or reverse proxy for access control
  • Optional HTTP Basic Authentication is available; enable it when exposing PortGuard outside a trusted network
  • Recommended: terminate TLS at a reverse proxy (nginx/Traefik/Caddy) when using Basic Auth to prevent credential leakage

docs.title: Added
docs.text:
• HTTP Basic Authentication support
  • Optional authentication with constant-time password comparison
  • Protects all endpoints (/health, /live, /)
  • Returns 401 with WWW-Authenticate header
  • Disabled by default for backward compatibility
  • Per-check timeout configuration
  • Each check can override the global timeout
  • Supports different timeouts per service (e.g., 500ms for local, 10s for remote APIs)

docs.title: Added
docs.text:
• Initial release - lightweight HTTP service for TCP port monitoring
  • HTTP endpoints: /health (JSON), /live (liveness), / (HTML info)
  • YAML configuration with multiple port checks
  • Configurable timeouts and per-check settings
  • Systemd service, Docker support, multi-platform builds
  • Single binary with no external dependencies
